The predictions were done using a deep neural network (DNN) publihed in Ulrich
column2: N. et al. (2021) "Exploring the octanol–water partition coefficient dataset using

column1: deep learning techniques and data augmentation. Commun. Chem.
The DNN model was developed using the DeepChem library v. 2.216
v.1.14.0 in Python v. 3.5.6. SMILES of the chemicals
were converted into graphs (ConvMolFeaturizer) and used as features. The
feed-forward network consists of two hidden layers with 64
which were connected to a dense layer (with ReLU activation function) followed by
batch normalization (including a dropout of 0.1) and the output layer (with tanh
activation function). Each hidden layer was constructed by a graph convolution
batch normalization and a graph pool layer. The DNN was

column2: with a batch size of 50 and the learning

column1: rate was set to 0.0001. Salts were removed for the input SMILES.
The model and model environment can be found on our GitHub repository
Partitioning of ions was assumed insignificant
the logP values of the neutral species by multiplying the neutral fraction.
Uncertainties are proided as the rmse found in model development.
